history.content:
Taking advantage of multithreading to speed stuff up as well as how it complicates processor design is a large chunk of the last third of 61C (the “parallelism” section of the course), along with a basic explanation of what a thread is in terms of hardware (a single core) and software (the most basic “unit of work”).



162 also goes into it for sure, although I haven’t taken it yet so I’m not the best source about how it covers multi threading, but you could check out this past semester’s website to get a better idea: https://cs162.eecs.berkeley.edu

—

 

162: the class does go over what threads and processes are, and in one of the projects you implement scheduling for processes. The class also does go over some amount of thread programming in C, but it isn’t really about taking advantage of multithreading in the same way that 61C covers it (parallel programming.) CS C267 is a graduate course on parallel programming if you’re interested.

Taking advantage of multithreading to speed stuff up as well as how it complicates processor design is a large chunk of the last third of 61C (the “parallelism” section of the course), along with a basic explanation of what a thread is in terms of hardware (a single core) and software (the most basic “unit of work”).

162 also goes into it for sure, although I haven’t taken it yet so I’m not the best source about how it covers multi threading, but you could check out this past semester’s website to get a better idea: https://cs162.eecs.berkeley.edu

Taking advantage of multithreading to speed stuff up as well as how it complicates processor design is a large chunk of the last third of 61C (the “parallelism” section of the course).

162 also goes into it for sure, although I haven’t taken it yet so I’m not the best source about how it covers multi threading, but you could check out this past semester’s website to get a better idea: https://cs162.eecs.berkeley.edu
Is threads/multi-threading covered specifically in any course? It wasn't covered in Java in 61B, so I was wondering if it'll come up in the future.
history.subject: Multithreading
